repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Second Primary Education
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Primary Education
            Development Project for Bangladesh were as follows: outcome
            was satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            significant; Bank performance was moderately satisfactory;
            and Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: in a sector-wide approach (SWAP),
            the leadership of development partners requires a mix of
            "hard skills", "soft skills", and
            flexibility. The World Bank proved to play an important role
            in supporting fiduciary processes and participating in the
            technical dialogue. While there is agreement that ownership
            is an important determinant of success, the concept of
            ownership is often seen as a dichotomous process either
            there is ownership or not. The World Bank expressed repeated
            concerns about the government's ownership of the
            program, for example, the use of consultants to prepare the
            macro plan and concerns that the government initially raised
            about a SWAP. No sector is an island and it is important for
            sector programs to coordinate with efforts to strengthen
            public administration and governance. A SWAP is an
            evolutionary process that requires flexibility and
            adaptation to succeed. With support, governments can
            transform monitoring and evaluation (M and E) systems from a
            pro forma system of collecting data to a powerful tool for
            monitoring and decision making.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Second Primary Education
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Primary Education
            Development Project (PEDP II) for Bangladesh were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was substantial; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory; borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes:
            usefulness of an education sub-sector approach. Under the
            project, the Government took increased ownership and
            activities began to be somewhat mainstreamed and integrated
            into the regular system activities. Harmonization of
            management, planning, procurement, accounting and reporting
            arrangements helped to reduce Government of Bangladesh (GOB)
            transaction costs significantly. Need for a robust
            Monitoring and Evaluation (M and E): during the early phases
            of PEDP II, it was difficult to obtain sufficient focus on
            results and timely reporting. Much of the information
            available centered around progress of activities instead of
            key implementation reforms and outcomes. Development partner
            coordination: use of the results-based financing approach,
            the pooling of development partners funding, and use of the
            Government's systems for PEDPII resulted in the
            development partners having more harmonized implementation
            arrangements and joint planning towards key program results.
            Implementation support: a Sector Wide Approach (SWAp) that
            uses a common results-based approach with Government and
            development partners, and implements through regular
            government systems requires joint responsibilities for
            supervision within an integrated Implementation Support Plan
            (ISP) defined before the SWAp is launched and ideally,
            adequately funded.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Second Primary Education
            Development Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Primary
            Education Development Project for Bangladesh is to reduce
            poverty through universal primary education and to
            contribute to sustainable socio-economic development and
            equity as envisaged in the Millennium Development Goals
            (MDGs), through the provision of quality primary education
            to all children in the territory of the Borrower. A
            level-two project restructuring is proposed to facilitate:
            (i) reallocation of the credit between unallocated funds and
            categories of expenditure for better utilization of funds;
            (ii) extension of the closing date from June 30, 2010 to
            June 30, 2011 (12 months) to permit time for implementation
            of several important activities to better achieve the
            development objectives, as well as facilitate a smoother
            preparation transition for the next program; and (iii)
            inclusion of some changes in the key performance indicators
            and targets which were agreed at the mid-term review to
            ensure consistency with newly available baseline data at
            that time.

            Education Development Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) :
            Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Second Primary Education
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Primary
            Education Development Project is to improve quality,
            equitable access, and efficiency in primary education
            through a sub-sector program approach. Specifically, the
            program will assist the Government to: (a) improve the
            quality of teaching and learning, and raise student
            achievement; (b) increase access to schooling for the
            disadvantaged; and, (c) strengthen planning and management
            of primary education, including establishing a national
            monitoring and evaluation system for primary education. This
            program is in line with both the Country Assistance Strategy
            (CAS) and sectoral goals, and the Interim Poverty Reduction
            Strategy Paper (PRSP), which aims to develop a
            cost-effective, and better managed primary education system.
            The first component will improve quality through
            organizational development and capacity building ,including
            program management, and monitoring and evaluation. It
            comprises three subcomponents, aimed at supporting
            investments which will result in improved educational
            management, including good governance of the primary
            education system, with a focus on increasing authority and
            accountability at district, upazila, and school levels while
            addressing fiscal, and supervisory irregularities in the
            sub-sector. The interventions proposed in the second
            component represent the core quality inputs of the project,
            and provide the framework for systemic and institutional
            change, interventions that are designed to ensure program
            schools meet the agreed primary school quality level
            criteria. Other interventions, linking capacity building to
            program implementation, would include strengthening primary
            education apex institutions such as the National Academy of
            Education (NAPE), and the National Curriculum and Textbook
            Board (NCTB), support for Primary Training Institutes for
            initial teacher training, and Upazila Resource Centers for
            in-service teacher training. The third component consists of
            a summary of all physical facilities requirements under the
            other components, and includes support for improving
            existing ones, and providing new infrastructure, facilities,
            furnishings and equipment. Finally, the fourth component
            focuses on promoting, and facilitating access to quality
            schooling for those children who have never attended formal
            primary schooling, or who have dropped out, mainly due to
            poverty. It also includes capacity building interventions
            which are essential for institutionalizing strategies, and
            processes critical for ensuring access for children
            disadvantaged by poverty, and special needs.

Bangladesh - Second Primary Education
            Development Project

TF030494-JAPAN CTF FY04 GENERAL: SAR

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Second Primary Education
            Development Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Bangladesh Second Primary Education Development Project,
            which constructs and repairs school facilities, including
            classrooms, resource centers, school offices, and sanitation
            facilities. Environmental aspects will be considred in both
            design and construction/reconstruction of buildings,
            latrines, and tube wells. Since arsenic has contaminated the
            tube well water, remedial measures will be taken. Engineers
            will sink/re-sink the tube wells into arsenic free layers
            and re-test the water of the new tube wells with the help of
            the health department to ensure safe drinking water in the
            primary schools. In geographical locations where arsenic has
            contaminated the tube wells, alternate measures will be
            taken. For example deep-set hand tube wells will be sunk in
            alluvial normal areas; half deep-set hand tube wells with
            Tara pumps will be used in high alluvial areas; ring wells
            will be used in hilly areas; and deep-set hand tube wells at
            designated lower depths will be used in saline-affected
            coastal areas. Water testing laboratories have been
            established in different districts and regional levels to
            test water quality--for bacteria as well as arsenic. For
            sanitation, twin pit latrines (alternating pit use) will
            ensure one pit is dry and made germ-free. The dried-up
            residual matter can be used as green manure. Building design
            and construction will incorporate environmental practices.
            They will ensure soundness to resist cyclone and tidal
            surges, withstand earthquakes of moderate magnitude,
            facilitate cross-ventilation, and minimize dampness with
            pre-cast hexagonal ventilators.
